keyTakeAways: Judge Sara Ellis expanded her temporary restraining order to require federal agents on the ground during protests to turn on body-worn cameras, particularly to prevent unmarked or unauthorized force deployment.

CBP agents in Chicago (over 200) are required to wear body cameras and are trained to use them, while ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued cameras and must go through Congress for approval.
ICE agents are trained in crowd control, use of force, and handling journalists, with explicit protocols to allow media observation without interference.
A protest incident involving Pastor Rev. David Black in Albany Park, where he was hit with pepper balls without warning, raised concerns about transparency and protocol during demonstrations.
Federal leadership, particularly in ICE, has been described as a 'revolving door' with frequent personnel changes, such as Russell Hott moving from Chicago to Washington, DC.
The Trump administration has denied media reports of tear gas being used without warning, with legal representatives asserting the judge relies on selectively edited media.

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis is actively investigating the federal government’s response to protests in Chicago during Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE enforcement operation that resulted in over 1,000 migrant arrests. In a recent hearing, she expanded her temporary restraining order to require all federal agents on the ground to activate body-worn cameras, citing concerns that agents deployed tear gas and pepper balls without warning. CBP agents are required to use cameras, but ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued them and must seek congressional approval. ICE agents have received training in crowd control and media handling, yet a reported incident in Albany Park involving Pastor David Black, who was struck with pepper balls without warning, raised serious concerns. Federal leadership has also been described as a 'revolving door,' with key officials like Russell Hott leaving the Chicago area. The Trump administration has denied reports of tear gas use without warning, asserting media bias. Judge Ellis plans to continue questioning top officials, including Hott and Bovino, to determine accountability and compliance with her order.
title: Judge Presses Federal Officials on Response to Chicago Protests
